message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Methods That Support the Validation of Agent-Based Models: An Overview and Discussion
Paper Abstract: Validation is the process of determining if a model adequately represents the system under study for the model’s intended purpose. Validation is a critical component in building the credibility of a simulation model with its end-users. Effectively conducting validation can be a daunting task for both novice and experienced simulation developers. Further compounding the difficult task of conducting validation is that there is no universally accepted approach for assessing a simulation. These challenges are particularly relevant to the paradigm of Agent-Based Modeling and Simulation (ABMS) because of the complexity found in these models’ mechanisms and in the real-world situations they attempt to represent. To aid both the novice and expert in conducting a validation process for an agent-based simulation, this article reviews nine methods that are useful for this process, including foundational topics of docking, empirical validation, sampling, and visualization, as well as advanced topics of bootstrapping, causal analysis, inverse generative social science, and role-playing. Each method is reviewed with respect to its benefits and limitations as a validation-supporting method for ABMS. Suggestions that may support a validation plan for an agent-based simulations, are also provided. This article is an introductory guide for understanding and conducting ABMS validation for developers of all experience levels.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the web search results, I found information about generative science and related computational approaches to social science, but the specific term "inverse generative social science" does not appear in the search results returned.

However, I can provide context about related concepts:

Generative science is an area of research that explores the natural world and its complex behaviors, exploring ways "to generate apparently unanticipated and infinite behaviour based on deterministic and finite rules and parameters reproducing or resembling the behavior of natural and social phenomena".

In the social sciences, computational social science is an interdisciplinary academic sub-field concerned with computational approaches to the social sciences, which means that computers are used to model, simulate, and analyze social phenomena. Robert Axelrod regards social simulation as a third way of doing science, differing from both the deductive and inductive approach; generating data that can be analysed inductively, but coming from a rigorously specified set of rules rather than from direct measurement of the real world.

The term "inverse generative social science" may refer to a specific methodological approach or sub-field that wasn't prominently featured in these general search results. If you're looking for more specific information about this particular framework or its applications, providing additional context about where you encountered the term or what field it relates to would be helpful.

Web search results for query: "Validation science"

Links: [{"title":"Verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_and_validation"},{"title":"Validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Validation"},{"title":"Data validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_validation"},{"title":"Scientific method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_method"},{"title":"Science Platform Aircraft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_Platform_Aircraft"},{"title":"Roel Wieringa - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roel_Wieringa"},{"title":"PLATO (spacecraft) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PLATO_(spacecraft)"},{"title":"COCONet - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COCONet"},{"title":"International Seed Testing Association - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Seed_Testing_Association"},{"title":"Kepler-289 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kepler-289"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about validation science:

## Overview

Validation is intended to ensure a product, service, or system (or portion thereof, or set thereof) results in a product, service, or system (or portion thereof, or set thereof) that meets the operational needs of the user.

## Validation vs. Verification

An important distinction exists between validation and verification in scientific and engineering contexts. Validation can be expressed by the query "Are you building the right thing?" and verification by "Are you building it right?" "Building the right thing" refers back to the user's needs, while "building it right" checks that the specifications are correctly implemented by the system.

## Applications

Validation science is applied across various fields:

- **Scientific Method**: The scientific method is an empirical method for acquiring knowledge through careful observation, rigorous skepticism, hypothesis testing, and experimental validation.

- **Data Science**: Validation is defined as the process of assessing by independent means the quality of the data provided.

- **Design Science**: According to the Design science methodology of (Wieringa, 2014), validation is part of the design cycle.

- **Statistical Analysis**: Statistical models go through a process for validation, for which one could even say that awareness of potential biases is more important than the hard logic.

Validation science is fundamental to ensuring that products, systems, and research findings meet their intended purposes and user requirements across multiple disciplines.

Web search results for query: "Empirical validation"

Links: [{"title":"Empirical evidence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empirical_evidence"},{"title":"Empirical research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empirical_research"},{"title":"Construct validity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Construct_validity"},{"title":"Validity (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Validity_(statistics)"},{"title":"Training, validation, and test data sets - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Training_data_set"},{"title":"Empiricism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empiricism"},{"title":"Test validity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Test_validity"},{"title":"Empirical measure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empirical_measure"},{"title":"False consensus effect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/False_consensus_effect"},{"title":"Statistical model validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_model_validation"}]

I've found search results for "Empirical validation." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Purpose

Empirical validation is required for a hypothesis to gain acceptance in the scientific community. Normally, this validation is achieved by the scientific method of forming a hypothesis, experimental design, peer review, reproduction of results, conference presentation, and journal publication.

## Applications Across Disciplines

**In Science and Statistics:**
In scientific use, the term empirical refers to the gathering of data using only evidence that is observable by the senses or in some cases using calibrated scientific instruments.

**In Machine Learning and Model Validation:**
In statistics, model validation is the task of evaluating whether a chosen statistical model is appropriate or not. To combat this, model validation is used to test whether a statistical model can hold up to permutations in the data.

**In Psychological and Educational Testing:**
Test validity is the extent to which a test (such as a chemical, physical, or scholastic test) accurately measures what it is supposed to measure. In the fields of psychological testing and educational testing, "validity refers to the degree to which evidence and theory support the interpretations of test scores entailed by proposed uses of tests".

## Key Principle

A central concept in science and the scientific method is that conclusions must be empirically based on the evidence of the senses.

Links: [{"title":"Causal analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Causal_analysis"},{"title":"Exploratory causal analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exploratory_causal_analysis"},{"title":"Causal inference - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Causal_inference"},{"title":"Causal layered analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Causal_layered_analysis"},{"title":"Path analysis (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Path_analysis_(statistics)"},{"title":"Granger causality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Granger_causality"},{"title":"Mendelian randomization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mendelian_randomization"},{"title":"Process tracing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Process_tracing"},{"title":"Structural equation modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structural_equation_modeling"},{"title":"Event tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event_tree"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of causal analysis:

## Definition and Core Concepts

Causal analysis is the field of experimental design and statistics pertaining to establishing cause and effect.(no content)Typically it involves establishing four elements: correlation, sequence in time (that is, causes must occur before their proposed effect), a plausible physical or information-theoretical mechanism for an observed effect to follow from a possible cause, and eliminating the possibility of common and alternative ("special") causes.

## Key Methodological Approaches

**Exploratory Causal Analysis (ECA):** Exploratory causal analysis, also known as "data causality" or "causal discovery" is the use of statistical algorithms to infer associations in observed data sets that are potentially causal under strict assumptions.

**Path Analysis:** In statistics, path analysis is used to describe the directed dependencies among a set of variables.

**Process Tracing:** Process tracing is a qualitative research method used to develop and test theories and focuses on (complex) causal relationships between the independent variable(s) and the outcome of the dependent variable(s).

**Structural Equation Modeling (SEM):** Structural equation modeling (SEM) is a diverse set of methods used by scientists for both observational and experimental research. SEM involves a model representing how various aspects of some phenomenon are thought to causally connect to one another.

## Important Caveats

"Correlation does not imply causation" is often summed up as the difficulty of causal inference.(no content)Data collected in observational studies require different techniques for causal inference (because, for example, of issues such as confounding).

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Agent-based model"

Links: [{"title":"Agent-based model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model"},{"title":"Agent-based model in biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model_in_biology"},{"title":"Agent-based social simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_social_simulation"},{"title":"Comparison of agent-based modeling software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_agent-based_modeling_software"},{"title":"Agent-based computational economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_computational_economics"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Agent-based modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Agent-based_modeling&redirect=no"},{"title":"GAMA Platform - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GAMA_Platform"},{"title":"Sugarscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sugarscape"},{"title":"AI agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agentic_AI"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Agent-based Models:

## Definition

An agent-based model (ABM) is a computational model for simulating the actions and interactions of autonomous agents (both individual or collective entities such as organizations or groups) in order to understand the behavior of a system and what governs its outcomes.

## How They Work

Agent-based models are a kind of microscale model that simulate the simultaneous operations and interactions of multiple agents in an attempt to re-create and predict the appearance of complex phenomena.(no content)The process is one of emergence, where the whole is greater than the sum of its parts—higher-level system properties emerge from the interactions of lower-level subsystems.

## Key Components

Most agent-based models are composed of: (1) numerous agents specified at various scales; (2) decision-making heuristics; (3) learning rules or adaptive processes; (4) an interaction topology; and (5) an environment.(no content)Individual agents are typically characterized as boundedly rational, presumed to be acting in what they perceive as their own interests, such as reproduction, economic benefit, or social status, using heuristics or simple decision-making rules.

## Implementation and History

ABMs are typically implemented as computer simulations, either as custom software, or via ABM toolkits.(no content)The idea of agent-based modeling was developed as a relatively simple concept in the late 1940s, but it did not become widespread until the 1990s, since it requires computation-intensive procedures.

## Applications

Agent-based models have diverse applications across multiple fields, including biology, social sciences, economics, and environmental management.

Links: [{"title":"Visualization (graphics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visualization_(graphics)"},{"title":"Visualization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visualization"},{"title":"Starlight Information Visualization System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starlight_Information_Visualization_System"},{"title":"Advanced Visualization Studio - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_Visualization_Studio"},{"title":"Visualization Library - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visualization_Library"},{"title":"Data and information visualization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_and_information_visualization"},{"title":"Visualize - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visualize"},{"title":"Visualize EG - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visualize_EG"},{"title":"Music visualization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Music_visualization"},{"title":"Wikipedia:VideoWiki/Inkscape Tutorial: Visualizing Demographic Data - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:VideoWiki/Inkscape_Tutorial:_Visualizing_Demographic_Data"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of visualization:

## Definition

Visualization, also known as graphics visualization, is any technique for creating images, diagrams, or animations to communicate a message.

## Types of Visualization

There are several major categories:

1. **Graphic Visualization**: Visualization through visual imagery has been an effective way to communicate both abstract and concrete ideas since the dawn of humanity.

2. **Data and Information Visualization**: Data and information visualization is the practice of designing and creating graphic or visual representations of quantitative and qualitative data and information with the help of static, dynamic or interactive visual items.(no content)The visual formats used in data visualization include charts and graphs, geospatial maps, figures, correlation matrices, percentage gauges, etc.

3. **Music Visualization**: Music visualization is animated computer-generated imagery based on a piece of music, with imagery usually generated and rendered in real time, synchronizing with the music as it is played.

## Historical Context

Visualization has been used in maps, scientific drawings, and data plots for over a thousand years, with examples from cartography including Ptolemy's Geographia (2nd century AD), a map of China (1137 AD), and Minard's map (1861) of Napoleon's invasion of Russia.

## Purpose

These visualizations are intended to help a target audience visually explore and discover, quickly understand, interpret and gain important insights into otherwise difficult-to-identify structures, relationships, correlations, local and global patterns, trends, variations, constancy, clusters, outliers and unusual groupings within data.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

2. **Data and Information Visualization**: Data and information visualization is the practice of designing and creating graphic or visual representations of quantitative and qualitative data and information with the help of static, dynamic or interactive visual items.(no content)The visual formats used in data visualization include charts and graphs, geospatial maps, figures, correlation matrices, percentage gauges, etc.

3. **Music Visualization**: Music visualization is animated computer-generated imagery based on a piece of music, with imagery usually generated and rendered in real time, synchronizing with the music as it is played.

## Historical Context

Visualization has been used in maps, scientific drawings, and data plots for over a thousand years, with examples from cartography including Ptolemy's Geographia (2nd century AD), a map of China (1137 AD), and Minard's map (1861) of Napoleon's invasion of Russia.

## Purpose

These visualizations are intended to help a target audience visually explore and discover, quickly understand, interpret and gain important insights into otherwise difficult-to-identify structures, relationships, correlations, local and global patterns, trends, variations, constancy, clusters, outliers and unusual groupings within data.

Based on the search results, "docking validation" primarily relates to molecular docking in computational chemistry and drug discovery. Here's what I found:

## Molecular Docking Validation

In the context of molecular docking, validation involves assessing how well computational docking methods predict the actual binding of molecules. Root Mean Square Deviation (RMSD) is the standard method of evaluating various software performance within the binding mode of the protein-ligand structure, specifically measuring the root-mean-squared deviation between the software-predicted docking pose of the ligand and the experimental binding mode.(no content)Resulting hits from docking screens are subjected to pharmacological validation through measurements such as IC50, affinity or potency measurements. Additionally, only prospective studies constitute conclusive proof of the suitability of a technique for a particular target.

For scoring functions used in docking, studies are carried out on a standard benchmark of protein–protein interaction cases, where scoring functions are assessed on the rank they assign to the best structure and on their coverage (the proportion of benchmark cases for which they achieve an acceptable result).

The search results indicate that docking validation is a critical step in ensuring that computational docking methods accurately predict molecular interactions before moving forward with experimental testing and drug development.

Web search results for query: "Sampling method"

Links: [{"title":"Experience sampling method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experience_sampling_method"},{"title":"Sampling (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sampling_(statistics)"},{"title":"Work sampling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Work_sampling"},{"title":"Survey sampling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Survey_sampling"},{"title":"Systematic sampling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systematic_sampling"},{"title":"Importance sampling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Importance_sampling"},{"title":"Convenience sampling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convenience_sampling"},{"title":"Cluster sampling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cluster_sampling"},{"title":"Morris method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morris_method"},{"title":"Gibbs sampling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gibbs_sampling"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of sampling methods:

## General Definition

In statistics, quality assurance, and survey methodology, sampling is the selection of a subset or a statistical sample of individuals from within a statistical population to estimate characteristics of the whole population.(no content)Sampling has lower costs and faster data collection compared to recording data from the entire population, and thus, it can provide insights in cases where it is infeasible to measure an entire population.

## Major Types of Sampling Methods

### Probability Sampling
In a simple random sample (SRS) of a given size, all subsets of a sampling frame have an equal probability of being selected, and each element of the frame thus has an equal probability of selection.(no content)In survey methodology, one-dimensional systematic sampling is a statistical method involving the selection of elements from an ordered sampling frame, with the most common form being equal probability sampling (also known as epsem).(no content)Stratification is the process of dividing members of the population into homogeneous subgroups before sampling, based on auxiliary information about each sample unit.(no content)Cluster sampling is a sampling plan used when mutually homogeneous yet internally heterogeneous groupings are evident in a statistical population. In this sampling plan, the total population is divided into these groups (known as clusters) and a simple random sample of the groups is selected, and the elements in each cluster are then sampled.

### Non-Probability Sampling
Convenience sampling (also known as grab sampling, accidental sampling, or opportunity sampling) is a type of non-probability sampling that involves the sample being drawn from that part of the population that is close at hand.(no content)Nonprobability sampling methods include convenience sampling, quota sampling, and purposive sampling.

Here are the search results for "Role-playing":

## Overview

Role-playing is defined as "the changing of one's behaviour to fulfill a social role", but the term has several applications across different contexts.

## Definitions and Applications

In psychology, role-playing is used to refer to the playing of roles in theatre or educational settings, taking a role of a character and acting it out with a partner, a wide range of games including role-playing video games, or role-playing games specifically.

Many children participate in a form of role-playing known as make believe, wherein they adopt certain roles such as doctor and act out those roles in character.

## Role-Playing Games

A role-playing game is a game in which the participants assume the roles of characters and collaboratively create stories, with participants determining the actions of their characters based on their characterisation, and the actions succeeding or failing according to a formal system of rules and guidelines.

There are several forms of role-playing games, including tabletop role-playing games (TRPGs or TTRPGs) conducted through discussion, and live action role-playing (LARP), where players physically perform their characters' actions.

## Training and Therapeutic Uses

Role-playing may refer to role training where people rehearse situations, alone or with others, in preparation for a future performance, with examples including occupational training role-plays, educational role-play exercises, medical role-play, and certain military wargames.

Tabletop role-playing games may also be used in therapy settings to help individuals develop behavioral, social, and even language skills, with beneficiaries commonly including young people with neurodevelopmental conditions, such as Autism spectrum disorders, attention-deficit hyperactive disorder (ADHD), and dyslexia.

Here are the search results for "Role-playing":

## Overview

Role-playing is defined as "the changing of one's behaviour to fulfill a social role", but the term has several applications across different contexts.

## Definitions and Applications

In psychology, role-playing is used to refer to the playing of roles in theatre or educational settings, taking a role of a character and acting it out with a partner, a wide range of games including role-playing video games, or role-playing games specifically.

Many children participate in a form of role-playing known as make believe, wherein they adopt certain roles such as doctor and act out those roles in character.

## Role-Playing Games

A role-playing game is a game in which the participants assume the roles of characters and collaboratively create stories, with participants determining the actions of their characters based on their characterisation, and the actions succeeding or failing according to a formal system of rules and guidelines.

There are several forms of role-playing games, including tabletop role-playing games (TRPGs or TTRPGs) conducted through discussion, and live action role-playing (LARP), where players physically perform their characters' actions.

## Training and Therapeutic Uses

Role-playing may refer to role training where people rehearse situations, alone or with others, in preparation for a future performance, with examples including occupational training role-plays, educational role-play exercises, medical role-play, and certain military wargames.

Tabletop role-playing games may also be used in therapy settings to help individuals develop behavioral, social, and even language skills, with beneficiaries commonly including young people with neurodevelopmental conditions, such as Autism spectrum disorders, attention-deficit hyperactive disorder (ADHD), and dyslexia.

Web search results for query: "Bootstrapping statistics"

Links: [{"title":"Bootstrapping (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bootstrapping_(statistics)"},{"title":"Bootstrapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bootstrapping"},{"title":"Bootstrapping populations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bootstrapping_populations"},{"title":"Talk:Bootstrapping (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki?title=Talk:Bootstrapping_(statistics)"},{"title":"Bootstrap error-adjusted single-sample technique - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bootstrap_error-adjusted_single-sample_technique"},{"title":"Bootstrapping (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bootstrapping_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Bootstrap aggregating - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bootstrap_aggregating"},{"title":"Bradley Efron - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bradley_Efron"},{"title":"Bootstrapping (finance) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bootstrapping_(finance)"},{"title":"Bootstrapping (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bootstrapping_(linguistics)"}]

## Bootstrapping Statistics

Bootstrapping is a procedure for estimating the distribution of an estimator by resampling (often with replacement) one's data or a model estimated from the data.(no content)Bootstrapping assigns measures of accuracy (bias, variance, confidence intervals, prediction error, etc.) to sample estimates.

### How It Works

This technique allows estimation of the sampling distribution of almost any statistic using random sampling methods.(no content)In the case where a set of observations can be assumed to be from an independent and identically distributed population, this can be implemented by constructing a number of resamples with replacement, of the observed data set (and of equal size to the observed data set).

### Key Advantages

The bootstrap procedure is recommended for situations when the theoretical distribution of a statistic of interest is complicated or unknown, and since the bootstrapping procedure is distribution-independent it provides an indirect method to assess the properties of the distribution underlying the sample.(no content)It is also useful when the sample size is insufficient for straightforward statistical inference, and when the underlying distribution is well-known, bootstrapping provides a way to account for the distortions caused by the specific sample that may not be fully representative of the population.

### Important Limitations

Bootstrapping depends heavily on the estimator used, and although bootstrapping is (under some conditions) asymptotically consistent, it does not provide general finite-sample guarantees.(no content)If one performs a naive bootstrap on the sample mean when the underlying population lacks a finite variance, then the bootstrap distribution will not converge to the same limit as the sample mean, and confidence intervals based on bootstrap simulations could be misleading.

### History

Bootstrapping is especially known as a technique proposed by Bradley Efron, which has had a major impact in the field of statistics and virtually every area of statistical application.

Based on the search results, here's information about computer simulation:

## Definition and Purpose

Computer simulation is the running of a mathematical model on a computer, the model being designed to represent the behaviour of, or the outcome of, a real-world or physical system.(no content)By changing variables in the simulation, predictions may be made about the behaviour of the system.

## Applications

Computer simulations have become a useful tool for the mathematical modeling of many natural systems in physics, astrophysics, climatology, chemistry, biology and manufacturing, as well as human systems in economics, psychology, social science, health care and engineering.(no content)It can be used to explore and gain new insights into new technology and to estimate the performance of systems too complex for analytical solutions.

## Historical Development

Computer simulation developed hand-in-hand with the rapid growth of the computer, following its first large-scale deployment during the Manhattan Project in World War II to model the process of nuclear detonation.

## Types of Simulations

A continuous dynamic simulation performs numerical solution of differential-algebraic equations or differential equations. Applications include flight simulators, construction and management simulation games, chemical process modeling, and simulations of electrical circuits.

The search results reveal that computer simulation is a versatile and widely-used technology across numerous scientific and engineering disciplines for understanding and predicting complex system behavior.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters
Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.
List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.
